data.text: Bike Touring with a Bivi or Tent?
Trying to consolidate my thoughts; bivi or tent? Planning a trip round the NC500. Which you you take and why Jay
Hammock
data.author: Donovan Jannaway

data.text: might be lacking trees on the north coast
data.author: Gareth Lamb

data.text: possibly ya I take a sierria designs highside with is less than 3lb fully packed. And a klymit traverse hammock pad and tarp all very light and packable my hammock is always my go to
data.author: Donovan Jannaway

data.text: yes I love my hammock too, especially since it fits me and the pup in haha
data.author: Gareth Lamb

data.text: i did think of it, an eve looked at the tree situation. Trees would a problem some nights. I have never slept ain a hammock and generally sleep on my side so I decided it would best not start on a 7 day trip. Sleep is too valuable. Would like to try it though
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: probably wise, but they are comfortable even on the side, but probably not the place to test new things.
data.author: Gareth Lamb

data.text: What are they like in wind and rain ? I have another trip that might be suitable and might involve stealth
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: If it‚Äôs cold then a mat like uses is perfect but they are great especially for speed in setup
data.author: Gareth Lamb

data.text: . if you were to buy one, what you you get? tarp to go over the top? size ?. might be a good one for the german forest (i live in holland)
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: I just got the accessories that went with my klymit traverse it's a double hammock the trap covers it perfect the sleeping pad is designed for it too along with the net
data.author: Donovan Jannaway

data.text: they look good, I just got the 2 person one from decathlon so it‚Äôs very basic but super strong just wish it had a net üòÖ
data.author: Gareth Lamb

data.text: Bush, Hedge, Bus Stop, church porch üëç
data.author: Rob Bailey

data.text: not planing on packing that much üòÇ
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: if you're able to handle the minimalization of a bivi, then that's a winner weight-wise. But we all make sacrifices for comfort, so it's up to you to make the call. Personally on long cycling trip I go tent, because quality of rest is important. For a shorter trip, or maybe one that was going to be extremely remote anyway, I might consider a bivi (for context, a random one night stop, I'd consider bivi experience to be superior to camping, but it's hugely subjective).
data.author: Owen Kelly

data.text: yea that the kicker they both weigh the same ! 480g. The bivi packs done thinner but longer. Its the subjective stuff that i keep bouncing around in my head. Bivi is easier to pitch. Tent has higher ceiling‚Ä¶.. what makes one or other more comfortable in your opinion
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Depends on your goals. If you're trying to ride it as fast as you can then the bivy is the probable choice. If you're touring the route then a tent is much more comfortable when dealing with rain and midges or just sleeping in general.
data.author: Jacob Ashton

data.text: Sleeping in a bicycle is really minimalistic. You can't get changed, there is almost nowhere to put anything but its light and okay for one, maybe two nights. It is also better for stealth camping because of the lower profile. A tent allows you to sit safely away from bugs and actually rest much better. My preference is definitely the tent
data.author: Philip Yates

data.text: Bivi with a vestabule... Use a pad a good sleeping bag... Easier to stealth camp... No fees to catch some zzz...
data.author: Adam Shay Van Cleave

data.text: I finally got a bivy but needed a place to put my gear. So got a light tarp. But with guy lines and stakes, the set up is only 20oz less than my so much more comfortable tent.
data.author: Michael Moak

data.text: Did the NC500 in June. If you want to lose your nerves to midges you can use a bivy. But a tent is a WAY better option. Unless you are so fast that you can do it in two days or three and you only sleep when it‚Äôs really dark and wake up before dawn to avoid those bloody little insects. I started with a bivy as plan. But then bought a tent in Inverness because i had just experienced what midges are and had no intention to have them on my face while sleeping
data.author: Paolo Capozzi

data.text: thinking this way, did you wild camp or use sites ?
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: twice wild camping and 4 nights in camp sites. It‚Äôs not an issue to find wild camping spots. Maybe on the last part on the east coast is a bit more tricky.
data.author: Paolo Capozzi

data.text: great news thanks
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Tent is king, bivy is just a ditch taco with extra steps n stuff to loose.
data.author: Chris Herrald

data.text: Slugs can't get you in a tent üòÜ
data.author: Marc Baker

data.text: defiantly a plus
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: can see the stars in a bivy though :)
data.author: Owen Kelly

data.text: Not if your asleep, so if your awake it must be a shit night's sleep üòÜ
data.author: Marc Baker

data.text: Well guys , thansk very much , i think that is decided. tent it is. especially after playing the midge game, he say we went and bought one in inverness !
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Tent all the time in Scotland. If its not to keep the rain out it's also to keep the midges out
data.author: David O'Donnell

data.text: MSR Hubba Hubba NX 2 great tent üëç
data.author: Derek Brady

data.text: Definitely a tent, the midges will be such a pain in a bivy
data.author: Dusty Miller

data.text: I lean toward 1pp tent as I like to have room for a little gear.
data.author: Darren Hocking

data.text: Tent for me. Packs up small, can read in it etc. Less miserable in 3 day rain lol.
data.author: Chris Lloyd

data.text: Bivvy or hammock which can be put up like a basha. I'm selling a hammock as it happens lol
data.author: Bobby Reilly

data.text: Big Agnes fly creek 1 ul
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: bit heavy but thanks for the tip
data.author: Julian Young

data.text: Tent üèï
data.author: Cornelius Battanburg

data.text: Traveling that distance through somewhere that remote, going to need a tent. Something light, spacious, capable of withstanding reasonable amount of wind and rain.
data.author: Robert Blane Crawford

data.text: Tent to escape midges
data.author: Tim Rbinson

data.text: I recently moved to a bivy from a tent. Couldn‚Äôt be happier. I splurged on the outdoor research Helium bivy.

data.text: nice isn‚Äôt it, i have the same one
